title: Great wood version of the flip top
text:
These wood flip tops work just as well as the metal version from the videos I've seen. Plus you get 4 of these for about half the price. And you can spin them on any flat smooth surface and not worry about scratching the surface. These are milled smooth and have a nice wood smell, no paint smell. They are colored with dye with a light urethane finish.

I noticed the tops of these are flat whereas the metal ones are not. So as an experiment, I sanded around the top edge of one, into a curve tapering to a point rather than flat top, thinking this is the way most tops are. But this didn't work - it would not spin for more than a second after it flipped. But this actually makes sense. It needs to have a sheared flat top because the center of gravity (COG) is not straight up and down as it's spinning. It's the perimeter edge that lines up better with the offset vertical COG when it's inverted. I sanded it back down flat and it works fine. I call this one "Stubby."

title: Another Great Hasbro Black Series wearable Helmet
text:
Hasbro's done a nice job with the entry into their line of Black Series wearable helmets. Hasbro addressed some of the criticisms of the Black Series Stormtrooper helmet, which looked nice, but was a difficult fit for some, and the voice electronics weren't very good.

In this Poe helmet there are no plastic straps. Instead there are 3 separable foam cloth-covered stitched pads (2 ear muffs and an upper piece). The cloth of the pads stick to any of the 7 built-in velcro discs inside the helmet. It's a tight fit for me with all the pads installed, but if you detach and remove the ear muffs, you'll get about an extra 2 inches of room in width. So while this helmet looks a bit smaller than the stormtrooper helmet to me, it is actually roomier inside and should fit most adults. With the ear muffs removed I can even wear the helmet with glasses on.

There are three speakers inside the helmet: two at the front top and one in the back rear. A recessed microphone is at the inside front left. The external swing-out mic is just for show, there are no electronics in it. There is no voice amplification in this one instead your voice simply activates one of a set of pre-recorded sounds that include bb-8, X-Wing and Tie Fighter engine sounds, laser blasts and explosions, that are all mixed together in surround sound. With no voice activation you'll hear a steady in-flight engine sound. It all gives you an impression that you're in the middle of a starfighter battle. And it works pretty well. You can also trigger sounds by pressing the outside disc on the right side of the helmet.

The yellow visor raises up-and-down and has detents to hold it in position. However, the blast shield above it is fixed. The paint colors, graphics, and light weathering of the helmet are well done.

The outer dimensions of the helmet in inches are approximately 11x9x12 (width, height, depth).

title: Plastic Base Too Light For Heavy Disc
text:
This works ok. The disc is metal and very heavy. But the plastic base for the mirror is far too flimsy and lightweight to accommodate the disc without a lot of flexing and popping and clapping noise. All of this means lost energy which reduces spin time. The product just doesn't implement well the design the patent describes.

I wanted to better stabilize the base, so under running hot water I very carefully removed the mirror from the base. Perhaps not something I would recommend. As I was doing so, the smell of whatever adhesive was used literally made me light-headed. I've used a lot of epoxies and adhesives, but none that smelled as strong as this, like really strong gasoline. The adhesive was soft and spongy, not fully cured. I carefully removed all of whatever it was and filled the gap between the base and the bottom of the mirror with air-dry clay to fill the gaps and to increase the weight of the base overall. It did help to increase spin time somewhat and got rid of the annoying galloping-horse-playing-steel-drum sounds.

title: Another over-hyped and hypermarketed Sphero product?
text: The BB-8 was just OK and didn't live up to the marketing hype and early reviews by Sphero-friendly bloggers.  Patrol mode was awful, and the one in this R2 appears to be just as poor.  Sphero needs to spend more money on product engineering and testing with sensors that allow it to perform the advertised functions well and less on marketing.  Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me again, shame on me.

title: A nice wall ornament and room fan
text: A nice wall ornament and room fan, though very loud and must recharge battery after 6 minutes.  As a quadcopter, well it doesn't work well for that purpose.  Cheap motors, blades, ESCs, and shoddy mechanical and soldering, and poor flight stability algorithm not matched to the hardware make your chances of getting one that flies very slim.  I gave into temptation when I saw this listing again, thinking others just didn't know how to fly it.  nope, it's just that bad.  Holding it while the motors are running, tilting it to each corner should cause that lowest motor to run faster than the others.  But it doesnt.  My back right motor runs slower than the rest.  And that means there's no way it can restablize after tilting that direction.  But it is a nice big piece of styrofoam.

title: Wham-O AirBlaster this is not
text: As a child of the 70's the Wham-O Air Blaster was one of my favorite toys.  It looked like a big cool ray gun and fired a precise focused ball of air. This air bazooka is no air blaster. This air bazooka is basically a collapsible bathroom trashcan with a hole in the bottom and a short plastic liner and rubber bands. What an innovative and inspired design.  Holding from the bottom while pulling back from above means it's hard to aim.  It's very loud and the plastic used in the liner is crinkly in both sound and appearance. With all the cracks forming in that plastic lining after minimal use, I don't expect it to last very long. This is a good idea from the past that's been implemented cheaply and poorly.

title: Great H501s replacement, if you know how to change the connector.
text: Nice replacement battery for Hubsan H501s.  No power fade at the end of the flight like with the original Hubsan battery.  You will need to change the connector though and probably shorten the wire length to make it fit inside the battery bay.  The battery itself fits inside the 501s perfectly fine.

title: Fun to fly, good power, though a bit wobbly
text: The Darth Vader TIE Fighter isn't exactly an aerodynamic shape, but Air Hogs managed to stay true to its form while making it reasonably flyable.  Compared to the underpowered RC X-Wing, this one has plenty of thrust provided by two tandem counter-rotating motors within the centerline duct.  You can maintain altitude with about 60% thrust.  After a few familiarization flights (and crashes), I was up to 100 feet flying wide circles searching for Rebel ships.  Level flight will requires a rather significant angle-of-attack, and with that pitch up attitude makes it look like it's being pulled along by an invisible string.  The compromise made in this design is a lot of wobble left and right (roll).  The thin rudder is just sufficient to provide controllable flight, though at times it looks more like a bat than a TIE fighter with the wobble  The trim knob does let you adjust the rudder's center position, but the right stick is not proportional, it's 3-position full left rudder, center rudder, and right rudder.  But all-in-all, this is true-to-form TIE Fighter that is flyable and fun out of the box.

title: Great hands-on kit for learning and play
text: It's too bad so many kids have attention spans than can be measured in nanoseconds.  But for those with an interest in science who can put down their cell phones long enough,, this is a great hands on way to learn some interesting simple applications of magnetiism.  And if your kids aren't fascinated by it, there's a chance your pets might.  My cat loves playing with the finished projects which take only a few mInutes each to set up.

title: Accurate Rogue One Stormtrooper Helmet
text: This is an unexpectedly accurate Rogue One stormtrooper helmet for the price.  The fit for an adult is a bit tight, but can be worn without a problem if you adjust the straps to extend around the full circumference of the inside of the helmet.  With a proper fit your forehead and bridge of your nose will press against the front of the helmet.  Not particularly comfortable for wearing a long time, but allows moving your head without the helmet slipping.  The recessed "gills" of the tube stripes and the tears below the corners of the eyes are detail features unique to the R1 stormtrooper done well in this design.  The voice changer does work, though it's not that loud.  This is a sturdy heavy helmet at 2.2 pounds.  The 3-piece design easily snaps together, though does leave some visible seams, but not too bad.  But for the original price at release, this is a very good deal.

title: Fun toy
text: A good buy as an add-on item.  My cat just watches it as he doesn't like the vibration.  But I have fun with it even if he doesn't!  The tail does tend to cause the hexbug to go around in circles.  I just removed the string and use the hexbug by itself.  Very innovative and interesting toy, and a smart way to market what is essentially a bullet vibrator that looks like a bug ;)

title: A Graceful but Delicate Plane
text:
This flies beautifully and gracefully and is very forgiving with the AS3X technology. It allows it to recover nicely from stalls and keeps it relatively stable even in light gusty wind, especially impressive given its light weight. Still, it won't prevent you from crashing. And this is where I deduct a star. It's quite delicate. You'll benefit from buying some foam-safe glue (Beacon FOAM TAC is a good one). The build quality isn't too good; the parts inside aren't very well secured to the body, and I'm having some issues with a sticky elevator servo. Other annoyances are the battery attachment to the underside with velcro isn't very secure, and the power cable often gets lost inside the body near the propeller housing (tweezers needed to pull it back out. And as others have noted the method for attaching the front wing with screws is dicey at best; not sure when it's actually holding it in place (when the screws fall out, it isn't). But aside from these sloppy construction details, I'd still recommend it because it's such a great flyer. I'm using a Devo 7e transmitter running Deviation 4.0.1 which includes support for the DSM2/DSMX protocol used by the UMX Radian BNF. No hardware changes needed to the transmitter.

11/08/2015 UPDATE: The sticky elevator servo cause me not to be able to recover from a nosedive and the crash caused the tail section to break almost completely off. I was able to glue it back on but the flight isn't as pure as it was out of the box. I called Horizon Hobby about my issues and they have sent me a replacement UMX Radian free of charge.

title: Big fan of Funko and Lost in Space, but Paint Job was Sloppy on This One
text: I'm a big fan of Funko and Lost in Space, but this B-9 isn't up to the quality standard I expect from Funko.  The paint job was sloppy.  The rule of "staying between the lines" I learned in kindergarten for coloring wasn't followed, particularly on the chest.  Splotchy glue is visible holding the top and bottom of the clear, undetailed dome head.  I should give it less than 3 stars.  But I just can't for a Lost in Space B-9!

title: This is the ROBOT I was looking for!
text:
As a Lost In Space fan as a kid, I had to get this after seeing a video of it. When it arrived I was a bit worried I'd bought a knockoff or different one because the "Try Me" button illuminated all the lights but didn't flash, nor did the red chest light didn't blink in synchrony with the single line of dialog it would say each time you pushed the green button on the side of B9: "Danger!, Danger Will Robinson!" Not to worry though, this one is the right one. The power switch on the bottom does this when set to "Try Me". When switched to "On", you get the fully alternating flashing of lights across B9, and the red chest light does blink with each syllable of the 15 different lines of dialog as its being spoken.

Minor quibble is that the arms on mine don't stay up past horizontal when extended. But considering his age, that's a fairly common problem.

I've seen the height of this toy variably stated to be 10" and 11". The correct answer is 10.5" with the head lowered and 11.5" with the head pulled up.

title: A great quad for beginners and seasoned flyers
text: The X11 is a great small quad for beginners but sporty enough to keep more experienced flyers entertained as well.  Easy to fly and durable with 2 rate settings with prop guards included.  Very good range with the included transmiiter controller as well.

title: BB-8, you're no R2-D2!
text: Amazon is about the only place I've seen candid accurate reviews of this BB-8. For the price this is a poor product designed in a short timeframe and rushed to market.  The only function that really works well is "Drive".  Other features like "Patrol" I would expect BB-8 to learn where objects are when it hits them. But it doesn't it just keeps running into them time after time. Some of the voice commands like go explore or look around hardly do anything. The R2-D2 interactive Astromech droid I've had for 10 years which has infrared and sound sensors is much more intelligent than this droid.  Online there is a BB-8 Users Manual but it offers no detail for any of the functions. Maybe with future firmware and app software updates this can be made to be a good product but at this point I'm going to return it while I still can. Perhaps I will have A New Hope when there is another thats more capable than this initial release version.

title: Poor reliability
text: Minutes of fun flying time!  Hours of frustration trying to figure out why it won't take off and why the throttle surges and drops!  Days to spend solving the mysteries within, whether it's a bad motor, a bad receiver board, or a bad transmitter!  Weeks of waiting for your spare parts you had to buy to arrive!  Develop your soldering skills as you frequently replace motors!  Treat yourself to the acrid smell of overheated, overloaded motors after each flight!  I've owned quadcopters by other manufacturers that have worked flawlessly through hundreds of flights with no components needing replacement other than the batteries.  They were so boring compared to the WL Toys V262!

title: In space no one can hear you smile
text: A cute alien?  Yep!  Though I was expecting this to be a bobblehead, be aware that it is not.  You can turn the head left and right but that's it.  Still I'm quite happy with the little bugger.  The paint job is really good as they nailed the slightly metallic gray/green color.  A funny pose too - ready to attack!  Purchased on amazon from vendor Toynk who packaged the item well, and both the alien and the box arrived in mint condition.

title: Great RC Quad Copter for the $  Terrible Instructions
text:
[[VIDEOID:1f2a3c880a660ba73bcdaf865374ae12]] How to set up your Syma X1 before first flight. I go through the following steps quickly in the video:

1) Place a charged LiPo battery into the slide rails on the bottom of the copter, but not all the way in.
2) Place the copter in normal top-side-up position on a flat surface.
3) THEN push in the copter battery completely. The red LED in the copter will flash (4 Hz). Do not move the copter from the flat surface.
4) The flashing stops for about 2 seconds. I believe at this point the initialization of gyroscopes, stabilization algorithms, etc. has completed. The copter has just learned where "level" is for this flight.
5) Next the red LED the copter will flash quickly. If you have not yet bound the copter to the transmitter, the following steps must be completed while the copter is flashing quickly to bind the copter and the transmitter. If binding has already been completed previously, timing is not important (transmitter can be turned on any time after the fast flashing starts) but the steps are the same to complete the connection between copter and transmitter:
a) Start with transmitter off and the throttle (left stick) all the way down.
b) If you want to switch from Mode 1 to Mode 2 (or from Mode 2 to Mode 1), push the fine tuning switch below the right joystick to the right as you turn on the transmitter.
c) Turn on power to the transmitter.
d) Push the throttle (left stick) all the way up then all the way down. You will hear a long beep from the transmitter.

The binding between the copter and the transmitter performed in step 5 seems to be persistent across copter and transmitter power cycles and battery changes. The transmitter also maintains Mode and Trim settings across power cycles and battery changes.

After step 5 you will know the copter and the transmitter are communicating correctly when lights are on steady (no flashing) on both the copter (red) and on the transmitter (blue).

Steps 1-4 must ALWAYS be done before each flight. If the copter darts off in random directions (especially after performing a level rotation-only maneuver), there's a good chance it's because the gyros weren't initialized properly. The key is to place the copter on a level surface BEFORE inserting the battery.

I've given the Syma X1 4 stars because it's a lot of fun, but 1 star deducted because the instructions are unclear, and in the case of how to set up the copter preflight, just plain wrong.

title: Additional weight, but even more power
text:
The fit is a bit tight under the canopy, and it is heavier than a standard battery. But you do get extra power such that the thrust-to-weight ratio is higher which gives better flying performance. I used this in a S107G "Special Edition" red white and blue S107G and charged with a 110v charger for Syma Mini Helicopters.

It's a good idea to check when you first get the battery that it has some charge (at least 3.0V). And of course fully charge it before flying with it. And don't fly it til it runs out. A fully discharged LiPo battery is effectively ruined.

title: People think Boone (the stuffed cat) is real!
text: Let me start by saying that I have a real black cat that looks very much like Boone, the stuffed cat. So when I first got Boone and placed a rhinestone collar on him like my real cat, Gordon, family members thought the stuffed cat was my real cat. Boone the stuffed cat is soft, about the same size as my real cat and a good doppelgnger. Even my cat had to sniff the stuffed cat to be sure. Great gift or just to keep yourself because black cats bring GOOD luck if treated well and given love. Good to put out as a Halloween decoration or all year. (The picture I've attached is my real cator is it?) You decide.

title: I do not recall ordering this item
text: Vine tells me that I ordered this item.  I do not recall this; it is not the sort of thing I would typically order.  However, if I did order it, I reviewed it at the time.  It is probably fine.

title: One of Nerf's best
text:
My nephew is a Nerf connoisseur, with an arsenal that is the envy of most of the neighborhood kids, so I asked him to help me evaluate this new Nerf gun. He says that at the time he got it, it was new on the market, and he was excited to try it out. He found that it requires four D-batteries, which are not included, but fortunately his parents had some on hand. The gun was pretty big, but not unwieldy. The setup, he says, was pretty easy. After inserting the batteries, you simply insert the clip into the slot. Then insert your darts, and you are ready to fire. To fire, you pull the rev trigger, and then the trigger itself.

Compared to other blasters, my nephew found that despite its size, it is very customizable. It fires very fast and the loading feature is a big plus; it is unique to this particular blaster.

In short, he would "definitely recommend it" to anyone who likes Nerf.

title: A superb science-oriented set
text:
I love, love, love this toy! I chose to review it because I have a third grade cousin on whom I could test the set, and it was a hit in every way. The experiments are well designed, and the instructions are easy to follow--something I think is extremely important. I also love how easy it is to clean up after you are finished--everything washes up easily. You will need a few extra items for some of the experiments, but most homes will have these things around--things such as baking soda and vinegar. This set claims to produce 50 experiments, but some of these are variations on one another, so I would say 25 is closer to the truth. Still, that is a lot for the price.

As a retired teacher, I appreciate well-designed toys that offer learning experiences as well as play, and this toy does not disappoint. It is perfect for those long days of summer when your child is bored. Parents will need to be involved, especially for younger children, but to me that is a plus. For the price, this toy cannot be beat. And it may give your child an idea or two for the school science fair! Highly recommended.

title: A super selection from Lego
text: While I do not have a great deal of experience with Lego sets, this one is superior to the others I have evaluated.  For one thing, the Hulkbuster is large, which is a real advantage for younger kids (around age 7 to 9).  Also, the set was not too easy to put together, but not too difficult, either, which is what you want in a Lego set.  Too easy, and your child is bored; too difficult, and he or she is frustrated.  If your child is interested in Super Heroes, I think this set is well worth the price, and I recommend it highly.

title: Easy to assemble and fun to play with
text: This Lego set was a hit with our nine-year-old cousin.  He was undaunted by the instructions; in fact, I think he barely noticed them.  He built the set quickly, and he had to fend off the advances of his five-year-old brother.  The set was easy to put together, and though the toys, once built, are a bit small, the kids had fun with them.  I thought the price was a little high; maybe you can find this set on sale somewhere else.  But if you child is into Lego building sets, he or she will probably like this one very much.  Recommended.

title: A wonderful kit; both fun and educational
text:
When I ordered this K'NEX kit to review, I had in mind my nephew, who is thirteen, and his younger cousin who is six. My idea was that they could play together with this building kit on a rainy day and perhaps learn something in the process, the older cousin helping the younger. Well, the kit is a bit young for the 13-year-old, and a bit old for the six-year-old, but I am not at all sorry I got this toy. The boys really enjoyed putting together two of the five possible toys, and decided to save the other three possibilities for another day.

The set itself is well packaged, with lots of small parts, and so not appropriate for very young children. The kids in our family love LEGO toys, and they liked this kit almost as much. I liked it for its educational value as well as its fun aspect. I also like the physics aspect; they boys are learning physics and engineering principles without even being aware of it. I would definitely buy more K'NEX products. Highly recommended.

title: A great building set
text: I love these magnetic building toys.  They are fun and creative for kids of all ages, and even adults will be intrigued.  I field-tested mine on an seven-year-old boy and a four-year-old boy, and both were entranced.  The toy seems durable and solid, and the four-year-old especially loved that it could be made to spin.  I wish the building sets were a bit less expensive, but as they provide hours of fun and creativity, I think of them as an investment. Highly recommended.

title: A nice beginning art set
text: This is a  fine art set for kids, though I do have a couple of concerns.  First, the positive:  The set is well packaged.  The pencils are vibrant on the page, unlike some less expensive colored pencils.  The pastels are nice, with an even greater variety of colors.  The set includes drawing paper and sandpaper.  However, there are just a couple of minor negatives:  The set is targeted at really young children, and I do not think most of them would have the small motor skills to manipulate such slim pencils and narrow pastels.  The right age is probably about eight.  I also think the set is somewhat overpriced.  You could get each of these items separately (and much more drawing paper) for less money.  That said, this is a nice set for a budding artist.  It would make a good gift, especially if you like all the materials in well packaged in one place.

title: A toy with great educational potential
text: I field tested this science kit on my 6 1/2 year old cousin, who is very bright and very interested in all things scientific.  He loved doing the experiments, and though some adult supervision is definitely needed, he could do most of the measuring and adding of compounds on his own.  I recommend this kit for anyone who is looking for a way to interest young children in science, especially elementary chemistry, or who want an easy way to do simple experiments.  Though some have criticized this kit for using easily attainable household products, I think this is a plus.  If you run out of the materials the kit provides, you can always replicate the experiments with your own household chemicals.

title: Great game, with one caveat
text: This game is based on the popular television show on the National Geographic Channel by the same name.  It is an excellent game--lots of fun for both adults and kids, and not hard to learn to play.  I think the age designation is too high; intelligent 8 year olds can easily play most of this game and enjoy it.  The only problem with the game is that once you see all the questions and answers, that's it.  You know what the "tricks" are and probably won't be challenged again.  What this game needs is supplemental question/challenge sets, similar to what Trivial  Pursuit produced when that game was popular.  You probably remember:  Trivial Pursuit--Sports or Trivial Pursuit for Kids.  Something like this at a reasonable price would be excellent.  The game itself is five stars, but the limits imposed by the cards detract (at least) one star.

title: A good game, but a bit pricey
text:
Battleship is one of those classic games that seems to have been around forever. I remember my brother (now in his 60s) playing it as a kid. I was intrigued by this new version, and as my nephew is a great Star Wars fan, I decided to field test it on him and his friends, who are all 11 or 12 years old. They all know and like the original game.

The directions to the game are easy to understand. The point of the game is to destroy the other player's fleet of ships. There is no difference between the Star Wars version and the original version except that some of the pieces are characters or ships from Star Wars. You could enjoy this game even if you had no previous knowledge of Star Wars, but it would appeal to you more if you were a SW fan.

I always wonder about the educational value of games, but this one, according to my nephew, has no educational value. There is some strategy involved, so maybe you could say that it sharpens a player's thinking skills. It is scaled quite small, and I am not sure it is worth the price. Still, if you like Star Wars, you would definitely have fun with this version of Battleship.

title: Delightful gross fun for kids
text: This is an excellent gift for any parent (or other interested adult) who wants to encourage in kids an interest in science in an engaging and fun way.  The "experiments" are not difficult, and they do not require too much parental involvement, though you may want to get in on the fun.  They do not require any special equipment that you would not be likely to have around the house, though you will need a number of common household items.  I actually think this is a plus, as you can do the experiments again and again if your child shows interest.  Many kids younger than eight would be interested in these activities, though they may need help reading the instructions.  We are having a hard winter here in northern Ohio, and I think many parents would love this science kit to help keep their children entertained and learning in a fun way on the many "snow/calamity days" we have been having.  Directions for the experiments are clear.  I do recommend this product.

title: Interesting but somewhat confusing
text:
I gave this game to my teenage nephew, who played it with several family members and friends. They found the instructions not really hard, but very long and involved, and it took awhile for them to figure out how to play the game. They tried to follow the rules, but ended up playing the game according to their own "house rules."

The game comes with a timer, which makes a very loud noise. They eventually stopped using the timer because the noise was so annoying. One player even thought that the timer might have been broken. The timer went off completely on its own, making that obnoxious noise. Another player, an adult woman, did not enjoy the game at all, but the teens enjoyed the aspect of the game that required you to draw or to describe a product or the logo or symbol for a product. The game seems to be a combination of Pictionary and Charades and Trivial Pursuit. The kids thought this was a good, creative game, with a combination of old and new products. This aspect of the game made it good for mixed age groups. As other reviewers have said, this game is best played in teams. I have the feeling that this experiment may have gone better if at least one player had really understood how to play the game so that so much time would not have been consumed in trying to understand the rules.

The teens are willing to give this game another try. I am going to edit this review after they do to see if they enjoyed the game more. I have a feeling they will, especially as they become more familiar with it.

title: Great game for the pre-school set
text: I selected this game for my young cousin Brandon, who is just a few weeks shy of five.  I am happy to report that he loves this game and has played it 6 times in less than 24 hours!  The object of the game is for the dog, Shelby, to steal as many bones as possible.  The bones are made of rubber, not plastic, and the dog dishes are sturdy cardboard (which may or may not hold up, given that many pre-schoolers are hard on games and toys.  However, the game is designed to teach counting and simple math skills, and it does this quite well.  Since the dog steals bones from other dishes, the children learn to do simple addition and subtraction.  At the end, children count the number of bones Shelby has stolen, practicing their counting skills in a fun way.  I recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a fairly sturdy educational game that a pre-schooler will love.  A testimony from Brandon's mom, Laura:  "I love this game!"

title: A hit with toddlers!
text:
I ordered this toy for my cousin's toddler, who is just a bit over 16 months old. Joey adored the toy from the very beginning. He quickly caught on, with the help of older brother Brandon (who is nearly five), how to keep the puppy reading and singing by turning the pages of the book. In fact, it was Brandon who figured out the toy and taught Joey how to use it completely, a testament to the user-friendliness and age-appropriateness of this toy. I thought the price might be a little high, but I must say it had provided hours of fun and laughter, as well as a good learning experience for Joey. I would guess that this would make a good "from the grandparents" toy, simply because of the price. I definitely recommend it--and the batteries are included, something I wish would become industry standard.

Update: After speaking with people who are more accustomed to purchasing toys than I am, I am going to change my opinion of the price. One person I spoke with said, "Thirty five bucks? For a puppy that sings and reads and moves? That is really reasonable." So I think I may be living in the previous century when it comes to price. This is a delightful toy, and I think any toddler would love it.

title: A Crayola Bonanza!
text:
Who doesn't love a shiny new box of Crayola crayons? When I was little, my family could not afford anything bigger than the school-required box--I think at the time it was 16 crayons. I recall looking longingly at the 49-count box, and the 64-count box was definitely out of the question.

So now, along comes this great box of 152 crayons, and I could not resist. I am tempted to say that you will find every color known to man in this set of crayons, but I have been to a paint store recently and I know that is not true. However, I feel safe in saying you will find every color you could ever want. The classics? Yes. Glitter crayons? Got 'em. Neon colors? Yup! There is even a handy-dandy crayon sharpener in the center of the box. The plastic cover is a bit flimsy, but that is my only critique.

Each summer, a group I belong to collects school supplies for needy children in our area. We scrutinize "Back to School" supply lists, and I note that every single school specifies a 24-count box of Crayola crayons. The competing brands are just not acceptable, and I think the teachers are wise to insist on Crayola. You just cannot go wrong. Happy artistic endeavors with your new rainbow of color!

title: Enjoyable  and fun
text:
I ordered this toy for my cousin's four-and-a-half year old son, who is really excited about dinosaurs. The toy seems very well made and sturdy, as if it will hold up to a lot of enthusiastic play. The toy was a little difficult to unpack (lots of plastic ties), but we eventually got it set up. Brandon loved seeing the little car come out of the dinosaur's rear end--he roared with laughter at this. Unfortunately, we could not figure out how to make the dinosaur "eat" the car. We decided to wait and see if Brandon's dad could figure out this aspect of the toy.

Brandon really liked this toy, even though it did not work as it was supposed to. I will update this review as soon as I hear whether or not the dad was able to get it to work as advertised.

Update--Brandon's dad was not able to make the toy operate as it should. Brandon still loves it, but he would love it more if it worked as it is supposed to. If anyone has any suggestions, I would love to hear them. Thanks!

title: Fun and educational
text: I gave the Colorama game to my cousin for her four-year-old, and I am happy to say that he loves this game and asks repeatedly to play it.  Essentially, this game is designed to teach a young child shapes and colors, and it has several levels of play, from very basic to a bit more complex.  You can play by concentrating on shapes only, on colors only, or on a combination of the two.  The game is fun for kids, and if Brandon is any example, they will like it even if they already have a good grasp of shapes and colors.  Brandon has a younger brother, Joey, who  at 10 months is too young for the game,  but I can see this as a game the two could play together in about a year, with Brandon "teaching" Joey all the ins and outs of shapes and colors.  This game is a good use of time and money,  and I recommend it to anyone looking for a fun way to reinforce the basics of shapes and colors.

title: Excellent and versatile tricycle
text:
When I saw the opportunity to review this Radio Flyer four-in-one tricycle, I was eager to accept: My cousin and his wife, who live a couple doors down the street, have a three-year-old, and they have just learned that they are expecting another baby in June. So I knew that this toy would be used in all four of its "incarnations" at one point or another.

The toy arrived within three days, even though I did not request any special shipping status.

The directions for putting the tricycle together are excellent and detailed. They are entirely pictorial, with no words at all, which is a godsend for those of us who labor for hours trying to read badly translated written instructions. Laura (the mom) put the entire tricycle together with only minimal help from Brian (the dad). Brian did have to help with Instruction #13, and also with tightening screws and bolts here and there. I was delighted to hear that one does not need an engineering degree to put this toy together.

The tricycle went together very easily for the most part. The handlebars are the hardest part of the construction. Laura recommends that anyone putting this tricycle together pull up on the handlebars after attaching the bars and the clamp to be sure that the clamp has tightened properly. She pulled up on the handlebars at least four times and was able to remove them despite that clamp being on. You just have to tighten the clamp as much as possible.

This tricycle seems very durable, though I will add to this review after Brandon (the three-year-old) has used the toy more. The canopy is very nice, and the straps on the seat will be great for the new baby when he or she can use it (at nine months or so). The cupholder that surrounds the infant in the seat will be great for the baby as well. My only wish is that the tricycle had rubber tires instead of plastic tires. We live in a somewhat rural area with no sidewalks, and the plastic tires may not hold up as well as rubber tires. The push handle, to be used for infants, adjusts to the height of the adult pushing the tricycle, which is a wonderful feature.

Now to the acid test: Does the child like the toy? Brandon has been off this tricycle only to eat and sleep ever since it was put together. He even attempted to get on it several times while his mom was putting it together, saying, "I should try it!" With winter coming on he will probably use it only in the house at first, but Brian and Laura have a huge basement, and riding his tricycle there will give him hours of play time.

I highly recommend this tricycle, especially if your child or children are young enough to take advantage of it in all its formations. The product description says it can be used from nine months to five years, and that sounds about right.

title: The best gift ever!
text:
I bought two of these sets, one for a six-year-old, tho other for a twelve-year-old. The six-year-old liked the toy well enough, but he needed a lot of help in putting some of the projects together. He loved the flying saucer project and set it off several times in a row. The 12-year-old, however, was completely entranced. He opened the box and immediately set about making a doorbell, a radio, a flying saucer, a Morse code program, a trombone, a typewriter, and several other projects--all before the end of his birthday party!. His sisters, one 14 and the other 12, were also entranced and had to be reminded this was their brother's gift. I do not recall ever giving a gift that has been this much of an immediate "hit."

One thing I wondered about: Are the kids really learning about electronics, or are they just following the diagrams? But I think that this approach is similar to the way kids learn a video game or a computer program: They do not read about it and analyze it; they just do it, and learn in the doing. If you ask as they are making a project, "Can you think of an application for that?", the learning will be enhanced.

I recommend this toy highly, and I am thinking of ordering the Snap Circuits 750 as a gift for all three kids for Christmas.

text: Grandkids love it. We've owned a lot of power wheels over the years and we have run them all to the ground. The kids love them so much and this one is no exception. It is unique and very fun. Easy to use as well.

title: Cute outfit
text: Great doll clothes, but didn't realize they were for a 14inch doll. I thought they would fit our 18 in our generation girls. But still very cute and my granddaughters are excited to get the right size doll to fit these.

title: For smaller dolls
text: I didn't read carefully and thought these were for regular sized American Girl and Our Generation dolls. They are for smaller 14 inch dolls not 18in. However they do look really cute and my granddaughters really liked them.

title: Nice gift
text: My 3 grandkids all love slime. I plan on giving this to my granddaughter for her 8th birthday. It appears to be similar to the small slime kits we have purchased at our local 99 cent store. It only makes a little slime, but definitely makes the kids happy when they want to make slime. My granddaughter will love the cute little containers to put the slime in, as well as the mix-ins and scents.

title: Granddaughters love these
text: Both my granddaughters (3,7) have several fingerlings and were excited when this one arrived. They loved the addition of the baby cub that can be attached to the larger one. It's very cute and fun to play with but I don't think it sees as much use as some of their other toys like LOL's and barbies. A fun gift for someone that doesn't have one.

title: Glossy white paper
text: My granddaughter tested this out with some finger paint and it worked well. It is white paper with a glossy coating to help finger paint slide around easily without ripping the paper. The paper isn't very thick, but not super thin either. I expected a little thicker paper for paint. But it did it's job well regardless. Overall while this is a good product I probably would purchase paper that is good for all mediums in the future not just finger painting.

title: Makes a great gift
text: Great ball for various games. We use it mostly for four square and it is perfect for that. We have also purchased these at target to give as gifts.

title: Cute toy
text: Both my granddaughters really enjoyed opening this toy and playing with it. They love all the surprise type toys, like LOL dolls. They definitely like LOL dolls more, but this was a fun change. Cute little toy that when you squeeze blows out a glitter bubble.

title: Granddaughter loves it
text: My 5 year old granddaughter loves Ninjago and legos so this made her really happy to receive. She can do a lot of it on her own but it's fun to help them with. Never had a Lego set that wasn't 5 stars and this is no exception. Would make a great gift as well.

title: Granddaughters give these 10 stars
text: My two granddaughters (3,7) are obsessed with LOL's. To say they loved this one is an understatement. They couldn't wait to open it and opening it is so much fun for them. There are lots of little things to open and all packaged in a fun way. Some are covered in kinetic sand and some needed to be dissolved in water like a bath bomb. They were both very happy with the mermaid doll and kitty they received. I also thought they were quite cute. Once everything is opened they can play with the kinetic sand as well as fill the large container with ice water and watch the dolls color change. My girls play with their lol dolls for hours everyday. Would make a great gift.

title: Great value poker set.
text: This is a very professional poker set. Good quality chips that feel and look professional. It comes with metal case with keys to lock it. It has really nice buttons for dealer, big blind, and small blind. Overall a great value set .

title: A bit expensive but daughters love them
text: My daughters love these automated toys. They know more about them I do. Basically they are like a little toy pet. They react to you plying with them. It's fun to watch them play with them an treat them like a real pet.

title: Grandkids love them
text: My grandkids (9,7,3) all enjoyed playing with these. The foam is fun to play with and the little toy inside is cute and can be played with in the foam.

title: Fun toy for the amateur user
text: Nice smaller RC car. It's fast but not 30 fast. Charges quickly and the battery last for about 30-40 min. I have taken it off a few larger jumps and it's survived them so far.

title: Great chalk
text: Great chalk. I usually by mine at the dollar store, but this seems to be a good deal for good quality sidewalk chalk. Fun to bring to the park, or for drawing four square court and hopscotch. All my grandkids (3,7,9) enjoy playing with it.

title: Cute mystery toy
text: Cute surprise style toy. If you child likes shopkins and lol's they will probably like this as well. Our came with two reversible stuffed animals that smell fruity like their other products. It also came with various little goodies inside like stickers, pen, tattoos. Majority of the fun for the item is opening it and finding what's inside. Granddaughter, age 7, likes this and likes having the larger one on her bed and throwing it around.

title: Cute interactive toy
text: Cute baby toy that my granddaughters (3 and 7) both really like. It is similar to a fingerling as others mentioned but slightly bigger. It is very interactive and fun for them to play with. But I think this is one of those toys that won't get as much use as their barbie dolls, lol dolls, and other baby dolls. I think some will enjoy it more than others.

title: Perfect for 7 year old
text: Got this for my 7 year old grandaughter who has recently been interested in performing magic tricks for the family. She usually comes up with her own, so I think she will really like this. It isn't the greatest quality or variety, but for the money it's a good value and the instructions are perfect for her age and abilities.

title: Perfect for 9 year old
text: Got this as a gift for my 9 year old grandson and I think he will really like it. He likes building things and making the marble mazes so this should be perfect for him. It does require glue, but everything else is included.

title: Cute toy
text: Cute mickey toy that would make a great gift for a child that likes Mickey and the Roadster. It has a lot of fun parts that should be entertaining and fun to play with.

title: Cute sand toy
text: Cute beach and park toy. My grandkids like it and it has fun features that make it a bit more exciting than a plain bucket and shovel.  Would make a nice gift.

title: Grandaughters love it
text: My two grandaughters (3 and 6) love this set. It has a treat variety of pretend play items and is different from other sets they have because it also includes a straighter which they think is a really fun addition. The little clips are also nice to play with and easy for them to use. Would make a nice gift.

title: Cute little play piece.
text: Cute toy. Grandson loves it. Comes with one truck and there is a elevator and ramp for it to go down. Good for smaller children.

title: Grandkids like them
text: Great little mini Thomas and friends set. Grandkids love it. Fun to line up or connect. Good for counting as well. Would make a great gift.

title: Grandkids like it
text: Cute sand toy set. I usually purchase the bucket and sand toy set that Costco sells because it is a great deal ($10) and includes a nice variety of toys. This set is very nice though and has some fun items that my grand kids like.

title: Grandaughter loves it
text: 6 year old grandaughter loves this. She loves finding rolly polly's and making them little homes in household containers so this is perfect for her. She also likes the accessories that it comes with.

title: Grandkids love it
text: Great toy cash register that all my grandkids enjoy playing with. They have had a similar one for many years and really enjoy playing pretend store and restaurant with it. This one comes with a lot of fun accessories and I'm sure they will put them all to good use.

title: Granddaughters will love it
text: My granddaughters (age 6 and 2) are both crazy about hatchimals, lol dolls, and shopkins. I plan on giving this to them in their easter basket and I know they will love it. They have a lot of the small hatchimals so this will be perfect for them.

title: Perfect for 6 year old granddaughter
text: My 6 year old granddaughter was very excited when this arrived. She's loves making jewelry and likes all the items this set includes. I agree with the other comment about the packaging needing to better since all the beads were all mixed up and spill out of them the package when you open it. Other than that it's a no school set.

title: Nice math tool for young kids
text: Still trying to figure out how to use this the right way. The book has a lot of good examples but it makes me feel like there is a right way and wrong way to use it. Seems like it would be more useful to get the 100 one since they will outgrow counting wishing 20 quickly. Overall this is a well made teaching tool and I'm sure we will get some use out of it.

title: Easy cleaning
text: Great bath squirt toys that's are better than most since you can take them apart for cleaning. My grandkids love them in the bath and taking them to the pool.

title: Great set
text: Nice uppercase and lowercase magnetically foam letters that are as expected. The best part is that they come with a nice plastic storage container and lid. Great for learning to spell and great for kids who need more visual and tangible tools for learning since they can feel the shape of the letters with their hands. We use these to stick on a dry erase board.

title: Granddaughters like it
text: My 6 year old and 2 year old granddaughters were excited when this arrived and put it together right away. They both enjoyed playing with it and the instructions were easy for the 6 year old to follow. This set is as expected and no complaints.

title: Grandkids like it
text: Grandkids (8,6,2yrs old) thought this was really funny and they enjoyed playing, especially molding the poop. Instructions were easy to follow. Setup was quick. Sometimes you can see out of the bottom of the blindfold which lets you see the mat, so to save time and keep it fair we just closed our eyes. Overall a fun game unlike any other we've played.

title: Nice set of large legos
text: Great little buntch of large legos. Not enough to build something magnificent but nice set our 2 year old loves. My one wish is that it came with a lid, other than that a very nice set.

title: Great family game for young ones
text: Classics candy land board game. Our family enjoys playing this game from yesteryear. Timeless classic that our little (2 and 6) ones love.

title: Great, classic toy!
text: Classic power wheels jeep with Wonder Woman flair. Granddaughters love this jeep (2 and 6 YO). The 2 YO. is also able to drive in a circle. Plenty of power to carry both of them around, and at the high speed it's more than fast enough. It's cool to see them learn the concept of driving at a very young age. Battery last for about 1 to 2 hours of use. Takes about 12 hours to charge. Over all great toy and product.

title: Granddaughter likes it
text: Cute educational baby toy that my 18 month old granddaughter seems to like. It's hard to tell what the cards are made out of, but they seem durable and slobber-proof. I like that it also includes numbers, colors and shapes. My only complaint is that while the little cartoon pictures are very cute, my granddaughter prefers pictures of real life animals as opposed to the cartoon animals. I think more realistic pictures would hold her attention a lot longer. But overall a cute toy that would make a great baby shower or 1st birthday gift for a boy or a girl.

title: Granddaughters like it
text: Cute baby doll. My granddaughters ages 1 and 5 both really like it and have been playing with it for hours since it arrived. My reason for taking a couple stars off is that I've seen cute baby dolls like this or better at target and Walmart for much less. Even the dollar tree has one similar to this baby. Even though it says it is 8.5 inches, it seems so tiny in person. But kids like it regardless of price and size.

title: Nice larger size Barbie
text: My 5 year old granddaughter loves this Barbie. The large size is great for her to play with and she loves all the accessories she comes with. Her favorite part is the very long hair.

title: Fun frisbee
text: Grandkids love it. Comes with batteries and is ready to go. It's easier to throw and catch than a regular frisbee. Lots of fun and would make a good gift.

title: Grandaughter likes it
text: My 5 year old granddaughter will play with just about any toy and as expected she loves this little set. It's a shame it doesn't come with at least one other figure like a DJ. Her favorite part is the table and little food to put on it. Another table would have been great since there is so much food. And also a place to keep and store the masks and accessories would have been helpful. But all in all the product is nice and comes as pictured and my granddaughter enjoys it.

title: Great classic game
text: My two grandkids ages 5 and 7 enjoy playing this classic game. Great game to play as a family and before bed. Great for preschoolers and learning to count. Also comes with instructions and a puzzle to play a cooperative version of the game which we haven't played yet.

title: Granddaughter loves it.
text: My 4 year old granddaughter loves this toy cash register. It allows for a lot of imaginative play and teaches counting. She was able to figure out how to scan stuff and use everything right away. When you scan an item it tells you how many coins to pay, for example it will say "1 coin" and you put a coin in the slot and it will tell you how many you put in. The only slight drawback is that the money amounts aren't real life, so the age on this is a bit limited since around 6 years old most kids are good with counting actual money and coins. So I would say this is great for kids 5 and under and for older kids a toy cash register like the one they sell at ikea would be great for pretend play.

title: Cute set of baby toys
text: Very cute set of baby toys that would be a great baby shower gift for a boy or a girl.

title: Granddaughter likes it
text: My 4 yr old granddaughter is not picky when it comes to dolls and toys and will pretty much play with any toy. This Barbie is no exception. I also like that it encourages imaginative play and doesn't require batteries.

title: Granddaughter likes
text: My 4 yr old granddaughter is not picky when it comes to dolls and toys and will pretty much play with any toy. This Barbie is no exception. I also like that it encourages imaginative play and doesn't require batteries.

title: Great classic game
text: 4 year old and 6 year old grandkids love this classic game. They wanted to play it over and over when it first arrived. Everything is packaged nicely. Nice simple rules that are easy for kids to understand. Would make a great gift.

title: Great doll, we prefer playing with her without water
text: My 3 year old granddaughter really enjoys playing with this doll. My only complaint is that the peeing feature is really messy and requires you to purchase more diapers. My granddaughter enjoys playing with this doll without using water and just pretending to pour tea.

title: Messy but kids love it
text: I agree with the other reviewers that say that an adult's review of this is much different than a child's. I would have preferred a way for her to make bubbles without such a mess, but my 3 year old granddaughter loves this Barbie, bubbles and mermaids, so it is a perfect toy for her.

title: Great toy
text: My 3 year old granddaughter loves this toy. It is fun for her to carry it around and pretend to fly it through the air. I like that it doesn't require batteries or make annoying sounds. My only complaint is that it doesn't come with another friend for Sophia to have a tea party with. Seems for the price it could include one more friend. But overall it is a nice toy that most little girls will love.

title: Fun game and toy
text: A nice game that caught my 3 year old granddaughters attention right away. A simpler version of the card game UNO. While it's a bit odd to draw the game pieces while looking at them and in the site of everybody else, it's helpful with young players to be able to guide them and help them figure out their next move. My granddaughter really enjoys just playing with the animals and the barn. The pieces are great for sorting and counting too.

title: Couldn't get mine to work
text: If your child is really into Barbies, they may like this. My 3 year old granddaughter has a couple Barbies, but I find this Barbie completely disappointing. After reading through the assembly and operating instructions several times I was not able to get this toy to function as described. The cape is constantly coming unclipped on one side and it is not easy for a young child to clip back on or even operate as intended. I find all the things protruding from her back in order to make the cape go up and down extremely awkward. The glitter on her cape and shirt also comes off a lot. It seems that with a bit more thought this Barbie could be great and operate a lot more smoothly.

title: Work well, kids enjoy them.
text: These look good and our 5 and 3 YO like playing with them. They work on the refrigerator and on our dry eraser board.

title: Fun and entertaining.
text: 5 and 3 YO love this bubble mower. Great entertainment for there age. They both really love bubbles and I love that I don't have to blow in order to make them. Easy and quick to setup.

title: Great Dora toy
text: 3.5 YO loves this toy. It lights up with several different colors in the tail. The fin at the bottom also spins around. After a bit of training our 3.5 year old was able to wind the fin up herself. She's a big Dore fan and now really like Dora and friends. Great toy if you child love Dora.

title: Great toy
text: My two granddaughters (18 mos and 3 yrs) both love this. They have enjoyed all of the fisher-price toys I have purchased for them, such as the Fisher-price Learn to say please tea set and the Stroll along walker/stroller.

title: Great educational gift
text: My 5 year old grandson enjoyed playing with this map. There is a lot to see and learn from it and I can't find anything I don't like about it.

title: Nice toy and gift for babies
text: This is a nice toy and gift for babies. I have found that some children like it more than others. My 16 month old granddaughter enjoyed playing with it..

title: A nice toy, but kids lost interest...
text: My 15 month old and 3 year old granddaughters enjoyed playing with this toy as soon as it arrived. They lost interest in it after about 10 minutes. While it's a nice toy, there is only so much you can do with it and not much room for their imaginations. I prefer some of the Melissa and Doug toys, like the little wooden bus they can push around and put the little people in.

title: Should keep most boys entertained for hours
text: So much to do with this set. And best of all they can use their imagination. My grandson is very pleased with it.

title: Nice toy phone for babies and toddlers
text: My 3 year old and 1 year old granddaughters love playing with this phone. Even though they have a few other toy phones, they are still curious about what all the different buttons do and what songs it plays.

title: Great for learning to ride a bike, if you can get your child interested.....
text: Great little balance bike if you can get your child interested in it. We have had a strider balance bike for the past 2 years that we haven't been able to get either of my grandchildren interested in. I see kids at the park zooming around on balance bikes and having a blast. But I think my grandkids prefer their scooters. My 2 year old granddaughter has a y-glider scooter and my 5 year old grandson has been riding his razor scooter for the past 2 years. I think they will eventually be more interested in bikes, but its still nice to have a balance bike around for when they get the urge to try to ride a bike. This bike was easy to put together and I like that it is less expensive then the Strider, but it doesn't have footrests like the strider. I'm not sure how important they are but I know my grandson has used the footrests on the strider.

title: Grandaughter loves it. Only includes one princess though.
text: My almost 3 year old granddaughter loves playing with this castle. She has it set up next to her Fisher-Price Princess Klip Klop Stable which she also loves. This was easy to put together and took about 5-10 minutes. I was a little disappointed that the picture on the box shows tons of stuff that is not included. It would have been nice if one additional princess was included. Cinderella's dress can be taken on and off by pinching together the bottom of the dress like a clothespin.. I like that this toy does not require any batteries and encourages creative play.

title: Great gift
text: My almost 3 year old granddaughter loves dolls and this doll is no exception. She enjoys playing with the items that came with the baby. I don't plan on allowing her to use actual water to feed her baby, so I don't see the 1 diaper as being a problem.

title: Grandson loved it.
text: My 5 year old Grandson played with this for over an hour the second it arrived at our house. It is easy to unscrew and fill up and operate. Some water guns are hard for little kids to use, but this one was perfect for him. He loved how many streams of water came out when he shot it. I don't think it goes as far as it says, maybe only 15 ft, but it is perfect for him.

title: Nice toy
text: I have yet to meet a child that doesn't love playing with a ball. My grandchildren both enjoyed playing with this, however their parents noted that the sound/electronic part of this toy did not add to the fun of it. They said it was just as enjoyable with the sound off, but a nice option for someone who might enjoy it.

title: Fun but the price seems a bit high
text:
From my daughter:
My daughter (22 months old) loved to play with this non-stop this for about 3 days after receiving it. For the past 5 she's only touched it once or twice.

She does still like to carry around the horse/princes dolls but doesn't seem to revisit the whole setup often.

It's neat toy but as other reviewers have mentioned I would have liked to seen the horse walk/clop all the way down the castle.

I think she will play with it more as she gets older.

Cons:
The price should be less for what it is (Currently $39.99).
To say these look like the real Disney characters is a stretch!
I Would rather pay half the price and not have Disney's name on it.

title: NOT as fun as the original
text:
I love the original UNO so this seemed like it would have been a good fit. UNO Blast is fun but I would much rather play the regular UNO with the family.

Don't like that there is nowhere to keep the cards after you're done playing, except in the top where they can fall out.

title: Generated little interest
text: My grandson and his cousins (ages 3-6) showed little interest in this game. Even with repeated attempts to play with them and the toy, they lost interest very quickly and started playing with a Melissa and Doug wooden school bus they had also just received. It did seem like a good concept for a game, but it was hard getting the pieces to stick, which made it more frustrating than fun.

title: Outstanding toy
text: Where do I begin? It's well-made and sturdy. It's easy for a child to play with, while using his/her imagination, so of definite educational benefit. Plus, it doesn't need batteries - always nice. Plus, not only did my 3 year-old grandson enjoy it, but so did my 1 year-old granddaughter. In fact, she immediately played with it a long time, obviously engaged with it so much I could see her mind working and enjoying figuring it out - no frustration. So, a great toy, plus reasonable in price.

title: Kids had fun with it
text: Kids really enjoyed it since it was something different. The game board is well designed, constructed and of higher quality than typical board games. Would prefer it to be more educational, with something to learn about space, while the object of the game is just getting from one end of the board to the other, while avoiding obstacles. So, for the price, there are other games as good, but cheaper like CandyLand. But, it is fine.

title: Pretty good, but definitely for at least age 7 kids
text: Definitely for the recommended age of at least 7. Tons of tiny pieces, but the instructions are pretty detailed and easy to follow. Similar to putting together a model car. Moving parts. Good for a parent and child to work on together. Also works with other Lego pieces. Also, since the toy relates to violent action, I suggest a parent/buyer consider whether he/she feels the child is ready for such a toy.

title: A disappointment
text: It takes a lot of batteries, took a little while to get the hang of, and you need a lot open of space, on a hard surface, because it goes pretty fast and is hard to control the direction it goes in, so not great in small to medium size homes with carpet. But, a child does start playing with it for a little while several times throughout the day even though he doesn't know what he's doing with it. He likes that when he moves around the wand it makes the car go. It's a cool idea with the wand, but I think I would prefer buttons or knobs to press and turn. I think for about $20 there are better toys to spend your money on. He prefers his dump truck that doesn't take batteries and he can push around himself.

title: Great for sniping bad cats
text: I love this little zip fire! I have a holster attached to the bed frame and when one of the cats start kicking up a fuss, I snipe them which is lots of fun.The gun has not leaked and it's got accurate aim and long range. One day I plan on ambushing my husband while he's in the bathroom while yelling  security breach !

title: These cards are a fun, engaging way to practice a foreign language
text: I teach Spanish and English.These cards are a fun,engaging way to practice a foreign language. The cards come in a sturdy acrylic box for storage.I love to take the cards on road trips.It drives my husband crazy! Also, I have had some great times with friends when I took them to dinner or a potluck at church. I spread a few questions on each table and the guests have a blast!!

title: Love it- nothing a hammer couldn't fix!
text: Absolutely love this.  It's compatible with my name-brand Christmas train.  At first, the wheels wouldn't turn, while too stiff.  It is impossible to get the axle all the way in the wheels, with just your fingers.  After getting it in as far as you can- set one side on a notebook (the paper-kind, not the computer-kind) and lightly tape with a hammer.  Lightly.  I repeat- lightly.  This seated the axles perfectly and they rolled on the track perfectly.  It doesn't take much force.  Tap lightly.  Tap-tap-tapperoo!

title: Fun, cute build
text: Fun, cute build and good value. No complaints.

title: Worst build yet
text: I've probably built 30+ off-brand building blocks and never had a set this bad. To double my misery- I bought two, to form a full tunnel. The directions were literally so tiny that I used an otoscope (to look inside an ear) to try to figure out what it said. Since the printing was low quality- I still couldn't make out numbers, or exact piece size. Some directions showed pieces not included. Roughly 20+ pieces missing between the two sets. Even with rearranging- I still had to dig in to my personal collection to finish it.  Unless you're an expert builder with a lot of spares and desperately need a train tunnel- avoid this set. I wanted to love it, but the directions were so small that I thought it was a joke. I assumed no seller would seriously send something unreadable.  I was wrong. Beyond the unreadable directions and missing pieces- the design is poorly executed and the roof refuses to stay in place. Due to the bricks being too loose- they just collapsed. Again- had to use my own bricks.

title: Works good
text: This is my first speed cube. Works good.

title: A lot of fun for joy much money
text: We've made buckets of these water beads and still have 3/4 of a container of the tiny beads left. These last a long time.
